head.supplied: ¶ Since I last wrote to you from Mount Murchison, ¶ Darling River, NSW. Letter not found. ¶ ¶ considerable progress has been made towards the final ¶ ¶ start of the party from Buloo. ¶ ¶ I shall n...

div.p:
I shall not dwell on events antecedent toour start from the mount,
i.e. Mt Murchison station.
as my despatch, forwarded tothe secretary of the committeesome days since, furnishes the necessary information.
See Herald (Melbourne), 19 October 1865, p. 4.

I started from Mr. Reed's on August23, and, after numerous delays and annoyances, I reached Nocalija on the morning of the 5th September. Notwithstanding all I could do, I only succeeded in getting on the stores a little more than half way.At Nocalija I met Mr. M'Intyre.We made the necessary arrangements, and started back with the camels the same evening,to assist the team, leaving our camels' load of stores behind. I kept close at heel, carrying water, returning with empty bags, carrying on more water again, and so forth, until the team-driver was fairly flooded intothe execution of his agreement,and I had the satisfaction of seeing all the things safely put down at Coraillal, eight miles from Nocalija, yesterday evening.

Meanwhile Mr. M'Intyre had proceeded with the horse party and horses up the river(Paroo). Ho purchased many fresh animals on the way, and the last account I had from him stated that hehad crossed over totheBuloo
Bulloo River, Qld.
with all the horses and men. On the way up the Paroo he hired two bullock-drays (which I found awaiting my arrival at Nocalija), to conveythe stores to the depôt camponthe Buloo. These drays are now down at Coraillal, and I expect them up here tomorrow with all the loading, themost of which consistsof 2½tons of flour, 5 cwt. of rice, 11 cwt. of sugar, 2 chests of tea, 3 cwt. of dried fruit (apricots, raisins), 5 cwt. of iron-ware, 1½cwt. of sundries.

I do not anticipate any further delay in getting the things to the Buloo. Fortunatelyno time has been lost absolutely, notwithstanding the delays I have noticed, as it has been Mr. M'Intyre's intention throughout to spell six or eight weeks at the Buloo, in order to put the horses intoprime condition, and to drill the men to their work. Hencethecommissariat party, which minemay be considered for the present, alone suffers. The camels, indeed, have borne the brunt oftheundertaking go far, and although wretchedly low in condition, from overwork and bad food, they do their duty excellently well. I had no idea of their inestimable value for our purposes until I witnessed these severe trials of their power. They will, of course, need a spell; but a month to them on good food is equivalentto twice that time for horses.

When these stores are safely set down at the Buloo, there will be no further delay to ouronward movements. If I assumed the date ofour final start from Buloo to be November1, I think I should notbe guilty of much error.

Mr. M'Intyre declares that ho will make the Gulf, or the point to which he purposes going, in forty days from Buloo. If so, we may expect to enter the actual search some time aboutthe beginning of the newyear.
Again thanking you for all your kindness, promising to write when possible, and to see to the interests of the expedition,
I remain, my dear Dr. Mueller,
